abstract.text: Creates a sample buffer with a callback to make the data ready for use.

inlineContent.text: The allocator to use for allocating the
for the media data. This can be
with backing memory but no data yet, or a
that already contains the media data. If
Indicates whether or not the block buffer already contains the media data.
should call to make the data ready. Can be
A description of the media data’s format. Can be
structs, one struct per sample. If all samples have the same duration and are in presentation order, you can pass a single
struct with duration set to the duration of one sample,
set to the presentation time of the numerically earliest sample, and
. Behavior is undefined if samples in a
(or even in multiple buffers in the same stream) have the same
Array of size entries, one entry per sample. If all samples have the same size, you can pass a single size entry containing the size of one sample. Can be
if the samples are non-contiguous in the buffer (for example, non-interleaved audio, where the channel values for a single sample are scattered through the buffer).
On output, points to the newly created

) should have only one element if that same element applies to all samples. All parameters are copied. On return, the caller can release them, free them or reuse them. On return, the caller owns the returned
, and must release it when done with it.
Example of usage for in-display-order video frames:
sampleTimingArray: one entry = {duration = 1001/30000, presentationTimeStamp = 0/30000, decodeTimeStamp = invalid }
Example of usage for video frames in out-of-display-order :
dataBuffer: contains 6 H.264 frames in decode order (P2,B0,B1,I5,B3,B4)
Example of usage for compressed audio:
sampleTimingArray: one entry = {{duration = 1024/44100, presentationTimeStamp = 0/44100, decodeTimeStamp = invalid }}
Example of usage for uncompressed interleaved audio:
dataBuffer: contains 24000 uncompressed interleaved stereo frames, each containing 2 Float32s =
sampleTimingArray: one entry = {{duration = 1/48000, presentationTimeStamp = 0/48000, decodeTimeStamp = invalid }}
Example of usage for uncompressed non-interleaved audio:
dataBuffer: contains 24000 uncompressed non-interleaved stereo frames, each containing 2 (non-contiguous) Float32s =
sampleTimingArray: one entry = {duration = 1/48000, presentationTimeStamp = 0/48000, decodeTimeStamp = invalid }

abstract.text: Represent time-based audio-visual assets with essential data types.
Creates a sample buffer with packet descriptions.
Creates a sample buffer with packet descriptions and a callback to make the data ready for use.
Creates a sample buffer with packet descriptions and a handler to make the data ready for use.
A reference to a block buffer instance.
An object that describes a media format descriptor.
A datatype that represents an item count.
A reference to a buffer of media data.
Creates a sample buffer with a callback to make the data ready for use.
Creates a sample buffer with an image buffer and a callback to make the data ready for use.
Creates a sample buffer with an image buffer and a handler to make the data ready for use.
Creates a new sample buffer from a tagged buffer group.
Creates a sample buffer with media data.
Creates a sample buffer with image data.
Creates a sample buffer with a handler to make the data ready for use.
Makes the sample buffer’s data ready for use by invoking its callback to load the data.
Client callback called by
A collection of timing information for a sample in a sample buffer.
Errors that occur when processing sample buffer objects.
A reference to a CFAllocator object.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A signed integer value type.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
A raw pointer for accessing and manipulating untyped data.
